EG.title: Land of Ham | Mizraim | Egypt
EG.summary: Land of Ham and early Israelite sojourn; Hebrews lived among dark-skinned Egyptians before the Exodus—affirming the African setting of Israel’s bondage and deliverance.

biblical_refs.note: Israel dwelt in Goshen and multiplied.
Oppression before the Exodus.
Confession of deliverance from Egypt.

historical_refs.claim: A woolly-haired Hellenistic type sculpture from Late Period Egypt depicts the Black Semitic-African features characteristic of the Israelites, Coptics, and Nubians, who were largely indistinguishable from one another in appearance and culture during this period. The bust’s woolly hair and facial form align with the Kushite-Israelite continuum that persisted through the Ptolemaic age.

historical_refs.claim: Tacitus (A.D. 70), in The Histories, records ancient traditions describing the Jews as an Ethiopian race who once dwelt in Africa and Egypt, tracing their dispersion from Crete and the Levant (Roman Territory)—corroborating the early Hebrew and Semitic identity of the Israelites.

historical_refs.claim: Thomas R. R. Cobb (1858), in An Inquiry into the Law of Negro Slavery, acknowledges that ancient historians like Herodotus described the Egyptians as "black and woolly-haired," affirming that "there were negroes in Egypt" during that period. While attempting to refute Herodotus through later racial theorists such as Cuvier, Gliddon, and Morton, Cobb’s concession preserves 19th-century testimony identifying the Egyptians as dark-skinned Africans of Semitic descent.
historical_refs.source: Thomas R. R. Cobb, An Inquiry into the Law of Negro Slavery in the United States of America, Vol. I (Philadelphia: T. & J. W. Johnson & Co., 1858), pp. 41–42.

images.alt: Cover — An Inquiry into the Law of Negro Slavery (1858)

p.42 — Notes on Egyptians, Ethiopians, and complexion debates

historical_refs.claim: A mural from the tomb of Hekanefer showing Nubian officials bearing gifts to Egypt — evidence of African-Nubian presence during the same centuries the patriarchs sojourned in the land of Mizraim.
historical_refs.source: Tomb of Hekanefer, Nubia (c. 1400 BC).

images.alt: Tomb painting of Hekanefer in Nubia, showing procession of Nubian officials

historical_refs.claim: Tomb of Menna mural shows workers with dark complexions, reflecting the shared appearance of Egyptians and Hebrews in the same land.

Plates show 1st–2nd Dynasty royal heads and later portraits of Ramessu II, Merenptah, Bak-en-khonsu, and Taharqa—evidence of continuous African features across periods.
historical_refs.source: W. M. Flinders Petrie, *The Arts & Crafts of Ancient Egypt*, 2nd ed. (London & Edinburgh: T. N. Foulis, 1910), plates p.67 (Earliest Dynasties, nos. 19–22) and p.87 (New Kingdom Sculpture, nos. 43–46).

New Kingdom Sculpture (plate: 43–46) — Ramessu II, Merenptah, Bak-en-khonsu, Taharqa

historical_refs.claim: Flinders Petrie’s *Arts & Crafts of Ancient Egypt* (1910) presents an early photographic and typological study of Egyptian art, showing the continuity of African craftsmanship and form from the Old to the New Kingdom. Among these are wooden carvings of girls from the XVIIIth dynasty, exhibiting distinctly Nile Valley features consistent with indigenous Egyptian sculpture.
historical_refs.source: W. M. Flinders Petrie, *The Arts & Crafts of Ancient Egypt*, London & Edinburgh: T. N. Foulis, 1910, p. 88.

images.alt: Cover — The Arts & Crafts of Ancient Egypt (1910)

IL.title: Israel | Canaan | Land of Israel
IL.summary: Central homeland of the dark-skinned Semitic Israelites—patriarchal promises, tribal inheritance, kingship, captivity, and prophetic return all center here.

biblical_refs.note: The Hebrew Abram called and promised the land.
Jacob at Bethel; covenant reaffirmed.
Commission to possess the land.

historical_refs.claim: Rev. S. C. Malan (1873), in A Short History of the Copts and of Their Church (transl. from Taqi-ed-Din El-Maqrizi), records that the ancient Israelites resembled the Nubians in complexion and features—dark-skinned and native to the same Afro-Semitic world that produced Egypt’s earliest dynasties. His account challenges later European notions that Israelite or African peoples were separate from the high cultures of the ancient Near East.
historical_refs.source: Rev. S. C. Malan, A Short History of the Copts and of Their Church (transl. from Taqi-ed-Din El-Maqrizi), London: D. Nutt, 1873, p. 72.

historical_refs.claim: Merrill C. Tenney (1967), The Zondervan Pictorial Bible Dictionary, defines the Hebrew term "ruddy" (’adhmōnî) as denoting a reddish-brown or earthy hue — a mark of beauty and vitality — in contrast to the dark skin of the Hebrews (1 Samuel 16:12; 17:42; Song of Solomon 5:10). This passage affirms that the Israelites were a dark-skinned Semitic people, with "ruddy" describing a glowing or vibrant tone within that range, not European paleness.
historical_refs.source: Merrill C. Tenney, The Zondervan Pictorial Bible Dictionary (Grand Rapids: Zondervan, 1967).

images.alt: Cover — The Zondervan Pictorial Bible Dictionary (1967)
Definition of Ruddy describing contrast with the dark skin of the Hebrews

historical_refs.claim: Rackham notes that among the prophets and teachers at Antioch was “Simon…surnamed the Black,” reflecting a recognized dark-complexioned Semitic presence within the earliest Israelite-Christian leadership of the first century.
historical_refs.source: Richard B. Rackham, The Acts of the Apostles: An Exposition (London: Methuen, 1901), on Acts 13:1.

IR.title: Persia | Iran
IR.summary: Land of exile and restoration—Media, Elam, and Persia housed remnants of the Ten Tribes; Semitic Israelites moved eastward into Afghan lands while preserving Hebrew customs and memory.

biblical_refs.note: Assyria deported Israel to Halah, Habor (Gozan), and the cities of the Medes—core Persian/Afghan zones.
Cyrus’ decree to return and rebuild.
Cyrus’s decree of return and Persian dominion from India to Ethiopia frame Israelite life across the Persian sphere.
Elam, son of Shem — early Semitic progenitor dwelling east of Mesopotamia.
Elam and the regions of the east appear among the places from which Israel’s remnant would be recovered.
Artaxerxes permits reconstruction.

historical_refs.claim: Hannah Adams (1818), in The History of the Jews, records Afghan communities claiming descent from the Ten Tribes; scholars like Sir William Jones noted names, customs, and language affinities linking Afghans to exiled Israelites.

historical_refs.claim: Elamite populations of ancient Persia descended from Kushitic-Semitic migrants out of the Nile Valley. Their art, inscriptions, and deities preserve African affinities, indicating that early Persians included dark-skinned Semitic peoples closely related to Egypt and Ethiopia.
historical_refs.source: Runoko Rashidi (ed.) & Ivan Van Sertima (co-ed.), African Presence in Early Asia (New Brunswick: Transaction Publishers, 1985; 10th Anniversary Edition), pp. 10–14.

historical_refs.claim: Early Sumerian and Elamite civilizations were established by Black Semitic and Black African peoples who transmitted advanced systems of science and mathematics from Egypt. The Abbasid scholars of Baghdad continued this intellectual legacy long before Europe’s revival.
historical_refs.source: Wayne B. Chandler, African Presence in Early Asia (1985), p. 300.

SA.title: Arabia | Arabian Peninsula | Saudi Arabia
SA.summary: Homeland of Abraham’s other Semitic sons—Ishmaelites, Midianites, and Edomites—through trade along desert routes.

biblical_refs.note: Trade with Arabia in Solomon’s time.
The Queen of Sheba’s journey to Solomon connects Ethiopian and Arabian Israelites.
Paul went to Arabia.
Job, an Israelite dwelling in Uz (Arabia), demonstrates Israelite presence among Semitic peoples of the East.

historical_refs.claim: The earliest inhabitants of Arabia were dark-skinned Semitic peoples of African descent. Groups such as the Mahra and Sabeans carried Africoid features and Nile-Valley traditions into Arabia; the lineage of Makeda (the Queen of Sheba) reflects enduring Afro-Semitic continuity across the Red Sea.
historical_refs.source: Runoko Rashidi (ed.) & Ivan Van Sertima (co-ed.), African Presence in Early Asia (New Brunswick: Transaction Publishers, 1985; 10th Anniversary Edition), pp. 10–14.

Busts and paintings depict the 'Black Arabs of Old Arabia' and 'Black Arabian women,' confirming the region’s dark-skinned Semitic ancestry.
historical_refs.source: Wayne B. Chandler, in Runoko Rashidi & Ivan Van Sertima (eds.), African Presence in Early Asia (1985), pp. 294, 297, 300.

historical_refs.claim: Rev. C. Freshman (1876), records that a branch of dark-complexioned Egyptian Jews—refugees who fled Egypt under Ptolemy Physcon (2nd century BC)—settled in Abyssinia. Known as the Falashas, they became powerful rulers in East Africa and, through isolation from Egypt and Jerusalem, became connected with the Sub-Saharan African diaspora.
historical_refs.source: Rev. C. Freshman, The Jews and the Israelites: Their Religion, Philosophy, Traditions, and Literature (Toronto: A. Dredge & Co., 1876), p. 112.

historical_refs.claim: Thomas R. R. Cobb (1858), in An Inquiry into the Law of Negro Slavery, records that "the Ethiopia of the ancients" was regarded as "an example of negro civilization." Yet his own citations acknowledge that classical authors called the Ethiopians "excellent" and "divine." This contradiction reveals how Biblical and classical Ethiopians — ancestors of many Semitic-line peoples — were simultaneously acknowledged and misrepresented within 19th-century racial narratives.
historical_refs.source: Thomas R. R. Cobb, An Inquiry into the Law of Negro Slavery, Vol. I (1858), pp. 42–44.

biblical_refs.note: Tirhakah king of Ethiopia marches against Assyria in support of Hezekiah, king of Judah.
Land beyond the rivers of Cush.
Parallel account of Tirhakah’s approach against Assyria in alliance with Judah.

historical_refs.claim: Thomas R. R. Cobb (1858), in An Inquiry into the Law of Negro Slavery, writes that "the ancient kingdom of Meroe… its high civilization and great power are almost beyond question… its situation at the head of the Nile, in the midst of Ethiopia, is positive proof of the negro type of its inhabitants." He then cites contemporary Egyptologists who labeled Meroë’s people "red" or "Caucasian" — in an attempt to detach dark-complexioned Hamitics or Semitics from Egypt’s intellectual achievements. This provides a case study for revisionism in racial historiography.
historical_refs.source: Thomas R. R. Cobb, An Inquiry into the Law of Negro Slavery, Vol. I (1858), p. 43.

US.title: United States | Americas

biblical_refs.note: Those are the ten tribes… who took counsel among themselves to go into a further country, where never mankind dwelt.
Her merchandise and her hire shall be holiness to the Lord.
The LORD shall scatter thee among all people, from the one end of the earth even unto the other.
By the rivers of Babylon, there we sat down, yea, we wept, when we remembered Zion.

historical_refs.claim: George Jones compares Tyrian and Carthaginian worship customs—especially child sacrifice to Moloch—with identical practices in ancient Mexico. He concludes that these parallels reveal a direct cultural link between the Canaanite-Phoenician world and the early Americas.
historical_refs.source: George Jones, The History of Ancient America (London: Longman, Brown, Green, and Longmans, 1843), pp. 141–142.

historical_refs.source: George Jones, The History of Ancient America (London: Longman, Brown, Green, and Longmans, 1843), pp. 272–273.

biblical_refs.note: Solomon’s Red Sea fleets to Ophir/Tarshish connect Israel with Indian Ocean routes and ports along India’s west coast.
Persian rule extended “from India (Hodu) even unto Ethiopia,” placing India within a world where Israelites lived and served.
Prophecy of recovering Israel’s remnant from regions eastward (Elam/Shinar), consistent with later settlements toward India.

historical_refs.claim: Hannah Adams (1818), in The History of the Jews, reports the Black Jews of Cochin under British rule (≈16,000), known locally as Beni-Israel; they preserved ancient Pentateuch scrolls and Israelite rites distinct from European Jewry.
historical_refs.source: Hannah Adams, The History of the Jews (1818), pp. 534–535.

historical_refs.source: Hannah Adams, The History of the Jews, from the Destruction of Jerusalem to the Present Time (London: The London Society, 1818), pp. 449–453.

Rome was home to dispersed Semitic Israelites—some enslaved, others free—whose presence shaped the spiritual and social landscape of early Europe.

biblical_refs.note: Aquila and Priscilla, Jews expelled from Rome by Claudius, show Israelite presence in Italy before Paul’s arrival.
Paul sails toward Italy under Roman custody, symbolizing the spread of Israel’s witness into Europe.
Paul’s ministry in Rome marks the presence of Semitic Israelites within the Roman capital.

historical_refs.claim: Thomas R. R. Cobb (1858), in An Inquiry into the Law of Negro Slavery, notes that in Roman society "Negroes, being generally slaves of luxury, commanded a very high price." He quotes Juvenal, who wrote that a Roman noble could not dine without being attended by "the dusky Moor, and the more dusky Indian." Cobb’s record confirms that these Semitic Negroes — descendants of dispersed Israelites and related peoples — held recognized social and economic value within the daily life of Imperial Rome.
historical_refs.source: Thomas R. R. Cobb, An Inquiry into the Law of Negro Slavery, Vol. I (1858), Book II, p. LXXXV.

historical_refs.claim: Godfrey Higgins (1836) documents that medieval and early European art often depicted Christ and the Virgin as black, aligning with an Afro-Semitic sacred iconography continuous with Egypt and the ancient Near East. He writes: "The Romish Christ is black in India, black in Europe… in all the Romish countries of Europe the God Christ, as well as his mother, are described in their old pictures and statues to be black."
historical_refs.source: Godfrey Higgins, Anacalypsis: An Attempt to Draw Aside the Veil of the Saitic Isis; or, an Inquiry into the Origin of Languages, Nations, and Religions, Book IV, Ch. I, Sect. 10, pp. 138–139 (1836).

ES.title: Hispania | Iberia | Spain

The Lord shall bring Israel into Egypt again with ships—echoing the later maritime dispersions through Iberian ports under slavery and exile.
He shall assemble the outcasts of Israel and gather those dispersed across the Mediterranean and Iberian lands.
Captives of Jerusalem in Sepharad (Spain) — Israelites among western lands.
Paul expressed his intent to journey into Spain after completing his ministry, marking early scriptural focus on the Iberian region.

historical_refs.claim: James W. C. Pennington (1841), records early descendants of the Negro race are of Semitic origin — linking them to ancient Israelites dispersed throughout Iberia.
